factoid: Véra said she should think not because there can never be anything wrong in her behavior.
Borís remarked that Natálya Ilynychna behaves very well to Véra.
Borís said he has nothing to complain of.
Natásha told Borís not to do something and said he is such a diplomat that it is tiresome.
Natásha used the word "diplomat" in a special sense popular among children.
Natásha asked why she bothers Borís.
Natásha turned to Véra and said Véra will never understand because Véra has never loved anyone.
Natásha said Véra has no heart.
Natásha said Véra is a Madame de Genlis and nothing more.
Nicholas bestowed the nickname Madame de Genlis on Véra.
Natásha said Véra's greatest pleasure is to be unpleasant to people.
Natásha told Véra to go and flirt with Berg as much as she pleases.
Véra said she will not run after a young man before visitors.
Nicholas said that Véra has said unpleasant things to everyone and upset them.
Nicholas suggested they go to the nursery.
All four persons left the room.
Véra remarked that unpleasant things were said to her.
Véra said she said none of those unpleasant things to anyone.
Madame de Genlis shouted laughing voices through the door.
Véra produced an irritating and unpleasant effect on everyone.
Véra smiled and was unmoved by what had been said to her.
Véra went to the looking glass and arranged her hair and scarf.
Véra looked at her own face and became colder and calmer.
The countess said her life is not all roses.
The countess said at the rate they are living, their means will not last long.
The countess said it is all the Club and its easygoing nature.
The countess said even in the country they get no rest.
The countess said theatricals, hunting, and other activities are part of their life.
The countess asked the other person to tell her how they managed everything.
The countess said she often wonders at Annette how at her age she can rush off alone in a carriage to Moscow, to Petersburg, to ministers and great people, and know how to deal with them all.
The countess said it is quite astonishing.
The countess asked how Annette got things settled.
The countess said she could not possibly do it.
Anna Mikháylovna said God grant you never know what it is to be left a widow without means and with a son you love to distraction.
Anna Mikháylovna said one learns many things then.
Anna Mikháylovna said that lawsuit taught her much.
Anna Mikháylovna said when she wants to see a big person she writes a note: "Princess So-and-So desires an interview with So and-So."
Anna Mikháylovna said she then takes a cab and goes herself two, three, or four times until she gets what she wants.
Anna Mikháylovna said she doesn't mind what those people think of her.
The countess asked whom Anna applied about Bóry.
Anna said her brother is already an officer in the Guards, while her Nicholas is going as a cadet.
Anna said there is no one to interest himself for her brother.
Anna said she applied to Prince Vasíli.
Anna said Prince Vasíli was kind.
Prince Vasíli agreed to everything at once.
Prince Vasíli put the matter before the Emperor.
Princess Anna Mikháylovna was enthusiastic, forgetting the humiliation she endured to gain her end.
The countess asked if Prince Vasíli aged much.
Anna said she has not seen Prince Vasíli since they acted together at Rumyántsovs' theatricals.
Anna expected Prince Vasíli had forgotten her.
Anna said Prince Vasíli paid her attentions in those days.
